Name: Panel with Eagle
Description: This oblong panel has a circular top, over which is a gable of two connected triangles. These are separated by a decoration in the form of dots. In the center of the gable there is a half flower surrounded by a half circle. Above the gable, there is an ornament of leaves. The gable is supported by two columns, the shafts of which are shaped like palm leaves. In the center of the gable, there is an eagle with plants at the sides of its talons. Beneath this decoration is an inscription in two lines that reads "EIPOCOBWE/OWNHOVCHC." No decoration is in the lower part of the panel. The upper portion is partly broken. The museum possesses over 200 such funerary panels with inscriptions, some of which are in Greek while others are in Coptic. Similar panels have been found in Alexandria, as well as in various places in Upper and Lower Egypt, especially Aswan, Akhmim, and Ashmunein. Some of them are carved in marble, sandstone, and limestone. Some are triangular, others are oblong with a gable at the top.
